text: Bottle. Pours clear copper to brown with a medium beige head. Aroma of malt, sweet caramel, bourbon and vanilla. Malt and caramel flavor with bourbon accents before a semi-dry finish. My favorite of the four.

Bottle. Murky reddish brown. Light carb. Sugary sweet nose, light sour, barrel, syrup, bread. Flavor is amazing. Rich sugar, rye bread, sweet, syrup, wood. Warmth is welcomed on the finish. This is FANTASTIC 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Shared 750 ml. bottle poured to snifters, showing a darkest brown color with some ruby highlighting at the stem, with a presentable layer of tan foam, and dots & dashes of lacing. The nose was malty, with lurking, barleywine-like alcohol, some roastiness, nuttiness, and dark fruit. Medium+ bodied, with fair carbonation, the taste was similar, with amped sweetness that revealed notes as caramel, brown sugar, barrel induced vanilla, and a bit of maple. Thinned a bit in texture, but supplied a good deal of warmth.

Pours a slightly darker golden brown than the 6 month, with less head. Aroma of more vanilla and booze from the bourbon, still the same caramel sweetness. Taste follows, big on the barrel, big on the booze, wow. Cool to do these side by side.

Draft at the Bruery. Aroma of raisin, ripe fruit, bourbon vanilla and hazelnut. Flavor has bourbon, hazelnuts, vanilla, oak, caramel, ripe red fruit and a long finish. Softer than 6 and somewhat better.

From notes. Enjoyed at a little get together at Dougs house on June 08 with Travis and Chris also in attendance. 750 mL bottle opened by Chris. Nothing like a night cap of the Bruery in traditional fashion. The pour is a darker brown color, with hints of light red shining through and a tiny ring of light khaki colored head. I can smell the booze as my glass is being poured. I dont even need to bring it in. The aroma, aside from the booziness, is very complex and good. There is a nice dark fruit blast right up front. The malts come in with a sweeter chocolate and a light caramel right after that. There is a nice lingering vanilla, and decent oakiness before the bourbon and booze control the finish. The flavor is very similar. There is a strong sweet caramel and chocolate malt up front that slowly makes its way through dark fruits and a hint of vanilla before finishing awfully hot and boozy. The complexity is what I really like. Its a little boozy, yes, but its very good. The mouth feel is a little thin and light for a beer of this magnitude. The carbonation is soft, but it just lets the booze dominate and the thinness is very apparent. The aftertaste is sweet malts with a hint of vanilla and a lingering booze.

Bottle share at CBC Islington as The Bruery Chronology 12, gold wax, 16.7%. Many thanks to Kennethen for this one. Very dark brown, red hue, foamy tan head. Aroma is boozy, meaty, wet wood, some vanilla, Bovril. Body is smooth with soft carbonation, quite oily. Taste is varnish, booze, spice, molasses, bourbon. Heavy sweet and alcoholic. Holy moly. Too much for me.

Bottle shared at the big Dave tasting at craft beer Co Islington. Many thanks to Kenny for this one. Dark mahogany brown coloured pour with a small mid tan head. Aroma. Is deluxe paint, solvent, jammy fruit, nutty, raisin, harsh alcohol. Flavour is composed of marzipan cherry bakewell, nutty, layered boozy cake. Palate is medium sweet, sticky, sticky. Spicy Rye. Jammy fruits.

Bottle at Craft Islington, thanks to Kenny! It pours deep brown with an adequate beige head. The aroma is big and sweet.... toffee, vanilla, creamy, creme brulee, bourbon and fruit cake. The taste is smooth, bitter - sweet upfront, then plenty of toffee, vanilla creme, banoffee pie, creaminess, vanilla, fruit cake and a good deal of alcohol warmth on the finish. Full bodied with fine carbonation. Creamy and boosty. Full on, but fun in small doses.

21st April 2016Craft Islington bottleshare. Hazy brown beer, tidy pale tan head. Palate is light, semi dry and has decent fine carbonation. Spicy start and then into tangy fruity bourbon. Tangy dark fruits. Oaky vanilla lightens the landscape. Alcohol warmth. Light semi dry finish. Its a big beer and its proud of it. Pretty drinkable for the abv.

75cl bottle shared at Daves tasting @CBC Islington, London. Big thanks to Ken for this one. It pours a clean brown copper color with a small off white head. Aroma is big bold sweet and boozy with notes of raisins bourbon caramel and vanilla. Taste is also big bold sweet and boozy with more notes of caramel raisins chocolate vanilla and bourbon. Full bodied with good carbonation. Overall, bold

Bottle shared in London - cheers to Kenny. Pours deep brown with a bubbly, off-white head. Ripe fruits in the nose, some fruitcake, toffee, grape. Medium to heavy sweet flavour with hearty fruitcake, gooey dates and figs, ripe berries. Full bodied, chewy, with fine carbonation. Warming finish, with loads of gooey berries, brown sugar, alcohol, brown bread, fruitcake. Great stuff.

Bootle at Islo, thanks to Kenwold, 21/04/16.
Murky mahogany Brown with a decent beige head.
Nose is rich fruit cake, tobacco, spice, toffee fudge, spice .Taste comprises rich liquid fruit cake , full on bourbonics,
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle thanks to Will. Pours a cloudy brown with medium beige head that lasts. The aroma is dark fruit, oak, vanilla. Medium mouth, boozy, vanilla, dark fruit, wood, very good.
Bottle - pours brown white head - nose/taste of vanilla, bourbon, oaky caramel, toffee and bread - full body.
Bottle. Brown pour with tan head. Sweet, vanilla, oak and bourbon aromas. Flavors sweet tones, barrel, vanilla, oak Flavors.

(750ml bottle) very cloudy deep caramel-colored pour, lasting fine tan bubbles. Nose is very sweet, caramel, brown sugar, bourbon, alcohol, charred oak. Taste is even sweeter, slightly charred brown sugar, rum raisin, dates, bourbon, caramel, one dimensional. Its good but very sweet and hard to drink a lot of. Delicious nonetheless.
Copper pour. Nose is booze and toffee. Taste is toffee, ash, booze. Sticky mouthfeel.

750ml bottle pours a dark brown color with a bit of head. Nice balance of the bourbon with toffee and brown sugar. The toffee is more pronounced than the Chronology 6. Richer bourbon flavor. And alcohol not so hot.

Bottle. Actually enjoyed this more than the 6-month, which is interesting because I thought that one was almost too heavy on the barrel character. Nevertheless, this beer seems to have more tobacco and cocoa, and less fruitiness. Barrel notes are still huge, but sugar is lower and the overall drinkabilty is improved.

Had 6 a while back in bottles, and 12 & 18 side by side at The Bruery. Differences enough to notice for sure, but not necessarily score them different (theyre all 4.1 or so).
Similarities in base beer to their AV beer. Barrel is sweet with vanilla and toffee. Theres a bit of a surprising depth in the 18 that wasnt in the 6 or 12, even though they are all what I refer to as diabetes beers. Good bordering on great sippers.

December 11, 2015 - bottle purchased from my membership. Brown pour with limited head. Aroma was bourbon, wood, sugar and toffee. Taste was consistent with the aroma, but the bourbon and wood were stronger.

A- pours a dark and murky apple cider brown with a loose latte colored head that thins to nothing. No lacing.

S- Booze. Booze. And more booze. It stings! Beyond that: Brown apples, raisin bread, vanilla, caramel, anise, cola, bananas and some astringent. 

M- medium to full tacky body with a scent burn. Mild carb.

T- caramel and toffee notes are strong with some peanut brittle. Bruised apples. Middle starts to snow more bourbon, vanilla and plastic Easter chocolate. A light balsamic. Ending is all bitterness and burning. Dry grasses and a little lemon. Some zinc and seltzer.

29 Oct 2015, tap at the Bruery. brown and faintly hazy. nose is toasted bread, noticeable alcohol, fruitcake, nuts. med body and mildly fizzy. this is the typical Bruery beer. heavily nutty fruitcake and alcohol that bites. not as sweet as most (which is good), dry wood notes. nice.

Dark mahogany brown in color... Aroma of bourbon, caramel, oak... Flavor is brown sugar, toffee, caramel, bourbon and vanilla... Solid old ale... Akin to their anniversary beers

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Murky brown color solid head. Boozy bourbon aroma. Taste is dried fruit soaked in vanilla bourbon.

On tap @ The Bruery. The turbid, lowly carbonated darkish/chestnut colored beer youd expect. Its got a huge barrel character, which isnt surprising either. Lots of bourbon, vanilla, and oak. Sweet maple syrup, caramel, and brown sugar. Lots of dark fruit and some notes of chocolate as well. Definite heat/alcohol to it, which I actually expected more of given the boost level.

Bottle..Pour is dark brown with a off white head..Nose is nice chewy caramel, spice, dusty oak, vanilla sweetness, very bold..The beer has really settled down and flavors are getting balanced with the added 6 months..Taste is nice chewy barrel, caramel, rich, vanilla, oatmeal cookie..

Thanks to jdurdz for sharing. Brown pour with an off-white head. The aroma is heavy on the oak with some vanilla and maple. The flavor is fairly boozy with some big caramel, maple, vanilla and oak. I also get some dark fruit. Thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
